title: 105_hr2560
content: The Act is titled the "Little Rock Nine Medals and Coins Act" and includes a section on Little Rock Nine Gold Medals with Congressional findings. The Congress recognizes the Little Rock Nine as civil rights pioneers who risked their lives to integrate Central High School in Arkansas, advancing the civil rights debate in the country and upholding the principle of unity. The Little Rock Nine, recognized as civil rights pioneers, integrated Central High School in Arkansas, advancing the civil rights debate and promoting unity. They have left a lasting impact on the nation and continue to strive for equality for all Americans. SEC. 102. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDALS. The President is authorized to present gold medals to the "Little Rock Nine" in recognition of their heroism and suffering in the cause of civil rights by integrating Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike a gold medal for each recipient with suitable emblems. Authorization of appropriation is granted for necessary funds. Authorized appropriation of necessary funds for carrying out this section. SEC. 103 allows the Secretary of the Treasury to strike and sell duplicate bronze medals of gold medals at a price covering all costs. The proceeds reimburse the appropriation used for the medals. SEC. 104 designates the medals as national medals. TITLE II introduces the Gerald and Betty Ford Gold Medal with a Congressional Gold Medal under SEC 201. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Gerald R. and Betty Ford in recognition of their public service and humanitarian contributions, commemorating various occasions in 1998 related to President Ford and Mrs. Ford's birthdays, their wedding anniversary, and Gerald R. Ford's election to the House of Representatives and approval as Vice President. The Congress authorized the presentation of a gold medal to R. Ford for becoming Vice President. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal with suitable emblems. $20,000 is authorized for this purpose. SEC. 202 allows the Secretary of the Treasury to sell bronze duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering costs. The proceeds reimburse the appropriation used for the gold medal. SEC. 203 designates the medals as national medals. SEC. 301 allows the Secretary of the Treasury to make bulk sales at a discount to the Jackie Robinson Foundation for unissued coins before January 1, 1999. The total number of coins issued cannot exceed the authorized amount. SEC. 401 requires a study on $1 coin design evaluation. The Comptroller General of the United States will commission a study to compare the public acceptance and fiscal impact of using the image of Sacajawea on the new $1 coin with the Statue of Liberty. The study will be designed in consultation with relevant committees and the Secretary of the Treasury. The study commissioned by the Comptroller General will measure public acceptance and financial impact of using different images on the new $1 coin, including estimating potential sales and the number of coins removed from circulation for collections. It will also consider other factors influencing the choice of image for the coin's obverse. The study commissioned by the Comptroller General will measure public acceptance and financial impact of using different images on the new $1 coin. It will convene focus groups and consult with relevant associations to test the acceptance of the images. A report on the study's findings and conclusions is due before January 31, 1999. The study findings and conclusions, along with recommendations, will be included in the report. Up to $350,000 of the study costs will be reimbursed by the Secretary of the Treasury from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. The Leif Ericsson Millennium Commemorative Coin Act is the short title for Title V. This title specifies the coin specifications. SEC. 502 of the Leif Ericsson Millennium Commemorative Coin Act specifies the specifications for $1 silver coins, including weight, diameter, and composition. The coins minted under this title are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary can obtain silver for minting coins from any available source, including stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins is specified under SEC. 504. SEC. 504 specifies the design requirements for coins minted to commemorate the millennium of the discovery of the New World by Leif Ericsson. The design includes inscriptions of the year "2000" and words such as "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design is selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Leifur Eiriksson Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 505 states that coins minted under this title will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint allowed to strike each quality. The Secretary can begin issuing these coins on January 1, 2000, but minting authority will end on December 31, 2000. SEC. 506 requires a $10 surcharge per coin sold, with the proceeds going to the Leifur Eiriksson Foundation for student exchanges between the US and Iceland. The Foundation is subject to audit requirements. SEC. 507 provides a general waiver of procurement regulations. SEC. 507 grants a general waiver of procurement regulations for goods and services needed for implementing the provisions of this title, except for equal employment opportunity laws.
